Palisades Parade, Rose Park Concert celebrate July 4th

The celebration of July 4th in our nation’s capital is just like it across the country. It’s an excuse to mark our nation’s birthday with parades, picnics and concerts.

Evans stalls gambling initiative amid concerns

D.C. Councilmember Jack Evans has stalled new D.C. gambling programs authorized without public hearings that would bring on-line gaming to District residents and local establishments.

Personal Shopper - Summer Holiday

I think I could have been a personal shopper in another life. It’s like my day job, but with clothes. And with the social calendar of summer in full swing, there are a bevy of opportunities for crafting looks that suit the occasion.

First fig

My candle burns at both ends;

It will not last the night;

But ah, my foes and oh, my friends-

It gives a lovely light.

Fire, smoke envelope Hook and Tackle Box

Flames enveloped the rear section of Hook restaurant on M Street Georgetown Wednesday at lunch time, filling the street with billowing smoke and fumes that affected nearby shops and passers by.

The controversy over the American University campus plan has moved from the streets to the D.C. Zoning Commission.

Yo ho ho and a bottle of rum

Just how many men on that dead man's chest, anyway? According to Robert Louis Stevenson’s sea shanty, you'll find fifteen. Thanks to Captain Billy Bones in “Treasure Island,” the alcoholic beverage most associated with pirates is rum.

Maxi Madness!

Yes oh yes, it's all about maximizing things this summer with maxi-skirts and -dresses! They work in so many different areas of summertime life - at the beach as a cover-ups or out for brunch on a Sunday afternoon or to a friend's night time rooftop party.

Current Correspondent

Liking my PINK bike

I spotted the tricked-out pink and green number in the window of Tickled Pink, a Rehoboth Beach shop known for its Lilly Pulitzer dresses. But this wasn’t a dress or any other cute, clubby attire. It was a bike--a beach cruiser with white and pink tires, a white seat and floral frame of daisies.

Georgetown University students awarded record number of Fulbright scholarships

Twenty Georgetown University students and recent alumni received Fulbright awards for the 2011-2012 academic year to study in 16 different countries. Last year, the university had 16 winners.

The Georgetown BID and Washington Harbour hosted over 500 guests Sunday at a Waterfront Summer Celebration including a steel drum band, face painting, a balloon artist, and a water balloon toss.

Things I want you to know about Eva Gabrielsson

After one year

I wait for a call that never comes

His number in my cell phone

I wait for a smile I never get

His photo on my wall

I wait for a caress I never feel

His jacket in my closet

Tricia's 10: UHOF

My mother always told me, “If you can’t say something nice, don’t say anything at all.” Does that maternal wisdom apply to blogs? It probably should, but I just can’t help myself. We have a folder in the Huntley & Co. files labeled “UHOF”.

Even hotties need a few showers to cool them off

International wine tasting at HSBC Georgetown June 24

HSBC Georgetown invites you to “Wines from Around the World” Friday, June 24 starting at 6:00 pm.

Terra sworn in as new chair of D.C. Arts and Humanities Commission

Judith Terra, an arts and civic activist, was sworn in Wednesday as chair of the Commission on the Arts and Humanities. The chairmanship is a non-paying post but comes with high recognition in the creative communities.

Colonial bread-maker joins Rose Park farmers

If you’re one of Bill Duran’s lucky dogs, Rose Park is the only place to be on Wednesday afternoons. Besides freshly made cookies and fresh water, this season, the farmers' market has some very special new human treats too.

Bringing Back The Brooch

In an effort to break away from the norm and expand my horizons, I've decided I want to bring back the brooch! It's a great way to add a touch of glamour to your look and is truly a classic piece every woman should have in their jewelry box!

Bartleby's Books lost lost their lease at 1132 29th St. in Georgetown when the building's owner announced unexpectedly that he was putting a restaurant in the space.

Georgetown U. worker seriously injured in fall

A male worker fell at least 15 feet into a vent shaft and suffered serious injuries at Georgetown University's Yates Field House, according to witnesses. After falling from the roof of Yates, he was airlifted and flown via a Medivac helicopter to an area hospital.

EastBanc submits plans for West End, again

Anthony Lanier's EastBanc has submitted its application to D.C. officials once again to build 10,303 square feet of retail, 172 market rate residential units, and 192 underground parking spaces around the West End Library and fire station at 23rd between L and M Streets NW.

Kinda back to the future with Y and X dorms

Catholic University’s decision, recently announced, to phase out its co-ed dorm arrangements in an effort to curtail binge drinking and casual hookups could raise the specter of how the National Lampoon’s “Animal House” filming location is handling rambunctious students nowadays.

Question at City Hall: Who you gonna call?

Knowledgeable folks around the District's city hall are saying that a major problem with Mayor Vincent Gray’s office is there is no “go-to” person there to get things done.

Depending on what type of designer (or consumer) you are, the thrill of decorating can be found in various stages of the process. If you are the inquisitive type, then “the hunt” probably tops your list.
